item.title: A toy project of single cell data analysis
item.description: Load R package # way to install R packages # install.packages(file.choose(), repos=NULL) library(Seurat) library(cowplot) library(Matrix) library(dplyr) library(ggplot2) library(reshape2) library(hdf5r) library(MAST) library(umap) library(tidyr) library(tibble) # data <- readRDS("group1.rds") # "C:\\Users\\chen tianhao\\Downloads\\group2.rds" data <- readRDS("group2.rds") Violin plot of: Number of observed genes per cell Number of reads per cell VlnPlot(data, features=c("nFeature_RNA","nCount_RNA")) QC and cell filtering percent.mt < 5 Percent.Largest.Gene < 20 nFeature_RNA > 750 and nFeature_RNA < 2000 Calculate the proportion of transcripts mapping to mitochondrial genes

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description: R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com. You can embed an R code chunk like this: summary(cars) ## speed dist ## Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 ## 1st Qu.:12.0 1st Qu.: 26.00 ## Median :15.0 Median : 36.00 ## Mean :15.4 Mean : 42.98 ## 3rd Qu.

item.title: A Plain Markdown Post
item.description: This is a post written in plain Markdown (*.md) instead of R Markdown (*.Rmd). The major differences are: You cannot run any R code in a plain Markdown document, whereas in an R Markdown document, you can embed R code chunks (```{r}); A plain Markdown post is rendered through Blackfriday, and an R Markdown document is compiled by rmarkdown and Pandoc. There are many differences in syntax between Blackfriday’s Markdown and Pandoc’s Markdown.

item.title: About
item.description: This is a my first personal website based on the blogdown package. The theme I used here was forked from @jrutheiser/hugo-lithium-theme and modified by Yihui Xie.
